question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate, professional responses. Make sure the code you create is executable for demonstration purposes. Design a dynamic web page that demonstrates oxidation-reduction reactions.

checklist.title: Is the oxidation-reduction reaction simulation correctly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code accurately models electron transfer mechanisms between chemical species. Check if oxidation numbers change properly and if the simulation follows standard redox principles. Score 0 if core redox concepts are missing, 5 if only basic electron transfer is shown, and 10 if multiple complex redox reactions with proper balancing are included.

checklist.title: Are chemical equations balanced and scientifically accurate?
checklist.description: Check if the chemical equations maintain proper mass and charge balance across the reaction. Verify that oxidation states are correctly calculated and displayed. Deduct 5 points if equations are unbalanced, and 3 points if oxidation state calculations contain errors. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the visualization of electron transfer clear and educational?
checklist.description: Assess whether the visualization clearly shows electron movement between atoms/molecules using appropriate animations. The visualization should help users understand which species is oxidized and which is reduced. Deduct 5 points if electron flow isn't visibly tracked, 3 points if the oxidizing/reducing agents aren't clearly identified. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the page include interactive controls for user experimentation?
checklist.description: Evaluate if users can interact with the simulation by changing reactants, concentrations, or conditions to see different redox outcomes. Check if the interface allows users to test hypotheses and observe cause-effect relationships. Award 10 points for comprehensive interactive features, 5 for basic controls, and 0 if no interactivity exists.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code handles edge cases such as invalid chemical inputs, extreme concentration values, or unexpected user interactions. Test if the simulation degrades gracefully under unexpected conditions. Code with strong robustness should provide helpful error messages and prevent simulation crashes, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the educational experience (e.g., 1. Real-time energy level visualization 2. Molecular orbital representation 3. Interactive periodic table integration). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar chemical calculations 2. Function modules unrelated to redox reactions (e.g., unrelated simulations) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance without educational value. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core educational functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating chemical logic/view/calculation layers), unit test coverage, and build process automation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern scientific visualization principles: 1) Color schemes that effectively distinguish chemical species 2) Clear spatial representation of molecular structures 3) Professional labeling of elements and compounds (correct formulas, subscripts, etc.). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for misleading chemical representations, and 5 points for incorrect scientific notation. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and educational?
checklist.description: Judge whether the animations and transitions enhance conceptual understanding: 1) Reaction speed appropriate for observation (not too fast/slow) 2) Clear visual distinction between oxidation and reduction processes 3) Meaningful color changes or visual cues that reinforce chemical concepts. Deduct 5 points for confusing animations that misrepresent chemical processes, 3 points for unclear reaction steps, and 5 points for transitions that distract from the educational content. The full score is 10 points.
